item.title: A sample page of images and captions
item.description: A sample page of images and captions All of these images are 800px on the long edge. It seems I just can’t pass up the opportunity to take a picture of a curved trail - in this case with a pond and meadow beyond.

item.title: Bokononism - Nothing but Foma
item.description: Bokononism is Nothing but Foma In Kurt Vonnegut’s Cat’s Cradle, Bokononism is the fictional native religion of The Republic ofÂ San Lorenzo, a small, fictional island somewhere in the Caribbean.

item.title: Cat's Cradle by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: âŸ° [[Resources]] Cat’s Cradle was Kurt Vonnegut’s fourth novel. …it was first published in 1963, exploring and satirizing issues of science, technology, the purpose of religion, and the arms race, often through the use of morbid humor.

item.title: Definition of Personal God
item.description: Definition of “Personal God” A personal god, or personal goddess, is a deity who can be related to as a person instead of as an impersonal force, such as the Absolute.

item.title: GSW's version of an original page
item.description: GSW’s version of an original page Editing Quartz runs on top of Hugo so all notes are written in Markdown. Folder Structure Here’s a rough overview of what’s what. All content in your garden can found in the /content folder.

item.title: Testing out footnotes
item.description: Testing out footnotes Here’s the syntax for footnotes again: Nullam tristique diam purus, at vestibulum nisi pharetra sed.1 Quisque et turpis tellus. Integer arcu nulla, venenatis id elit non, ornare euismod tellus.

item.title: The last rites of Bokononism
item.description: âŸ° [[Cat’s Cradle by Kurt Vonnegut]] The last rites of Bokononism Throughout the 127 short chapters of Kurt Vonnegut’s Cat’s Cradle our point of view bounces here, then there, and then suddenly, through the narrator’s eye’s, we’re witnessing the the last rites of “Papa’’ Monzano, the country’s reigning dictator.
